values:
LiveJournal, I don't really know how to tell you this, but I think it's time. We've been together off-and-on for about three and a half years now, and we've had some good times together. You know that I haven't always been the most attentive person in the world, but we understood each other and it worked. But I'm done with college now and it's a big time of change for me; I think it's time that you and I called it quits.

No, it's not that there's anything wrong with you! You've been great. Sure, some of your formatting caused frustrations and there were more than a few limitations on what I could do with you (though I admit, you were a lot more...flexible than I initially anticipated), but all in all, things were great. I'm sorry, but it was bound to happen. Look, people change, grow up. No, I'm not saying that you're 'childish'! I just think that it's time for me to try something new for a while.

It's just...I've found someone knew. She's called Blogger, and not only is there much improved functionality, but it's also tied in with other blogs I could set up and to my Google account. I know, I know, how is anyone supposed to compete with Google? I'm not saying it's fair, LJ, I'm just telling you how it's going to be.

My new blog is going to be a little more...structured. Rather than writing about my life, which I don't think anyone really wanted to read anyways, I'm going to write more about the world and about all the crazy things about it. I even named it something random, "a day in the life of a shoe," which I think is a sign of how this time it's going to be less about me and more about how I see the world. Yeah, I know the title's a little weird, but I explain what it means in the first post. Hey, it may be a bit unconventional as titles go, but there's no need to resort to name-calling.

Look, this is a chance for both of us to start anew. We've been great together and I have no doubt that you'll find someone who'll be better for you than I ever was. I'm sure we'll both be happier this way. It may be hard now, but you'll understand soon. And hey, if you want to read it sometime, you can check it out here. Maybe we can be friends again someday, LiveJournal. I'd like that.

-Jon
I'm done with college. And have an advanced degree! Do they give those things out to just anyone these days? Jeeze.
This guy. So much for epic adventure. :-( A regular old road trip should be fun, though, right?

So, there's a story of these seven guys in ancient Ephesus who slept for 200 years. They were Christians at a time when it wasn't a good idea to be a Christian, and their refusal to sacrifice in the Imperial Temple got them labeled as enemies of the state, so they ran off into the nearby caves to form a plan. They laid down to take a nap and when they woke up to get some bread from the city, they discovered that it was 200 years later and Christianity was now the religion of the whole empire.

This is all well and good and I bet they were pretty happy to hear they wouldn't be tortured anymore, but my question is this; if someone had fallen asleep in a cave in 1808 and woken up today, a change in state religion would be the least of the shocks in store for them, but intuitively we don't see there being that big of a difference in daily life between 250AD and 450AD. Is that wrong or has the rate of change in the world been radically accelerated in the last few centuries? 

It's very easy to say that it has, that technological development is the most important driver of change and that having a new kind of well is not the same as having the cars, iPhones, hospitals and readily accessible pornography but that kind of presentism (is that a word?) makes me nervous. Historians may quibble over the effect of Constantine and later Christian emperors, but there would definitely have been a marked difference in life between 250 and 450; would people at the time have felt it the same way as we do today?

This is far more interesting than writing my papers.
I just went to sell 35 of my old course books back to the bookstore; they rejected a bunch of them and I got ~$135 total; not bad, not bad...

I had a fun present in my mailbox today from John McCain and my buddies over at the GOP. It's some of the most blatant propaganda I've ever seen, though it's couched in a "Critical Issues Survey" to help them get their "Victory 2008" program going; keep in mind that I like McCain and typically vote Republican and I think this is nuts. Here are a few samples: Do you believe our economy will grow if we cut taxes and put more money in the hands of hardworking Americans who pay taxes? (hint: if you say 'no,' they revoke your GOP membership card.) Which of the following factors do you feel is most adversely affecting the economy in your are? a) Burdensome taxes b) Unstable Real Estate Market c) Threat of Terrorism (yes, you read that right) d) Severe Government regulations e) Growth of Government Spending f) Unpredictable Fluctuating Fuel Prices Should America surrender in Iraq regardless of the consequences in the Middle East? Should we appoint judges who will interpret the law instead of liberal activists who will make new laws from the bench? Do you think we should work to give parents with children trapped in failing schools more choices to help their children have a better future? (no, John, I'm opposed to better futures) Do you think that forcing every American into a socialize national health care system is the best way to deal with uninsured patients? Should the Victory 2008 program be focused on turning out the Republican vote and registering 2 million new Republican voters? The thing ends with a choice between two options. One is "I support VICTORY 2008 (it really is all caps and bold) and am enclosing my most generous contribution of:" and the other is (in smaller print) "Yes, I support the Victory 2008 program, but I am unable to participate at this time. However, I have enclosed $15 to cover the cost of tabulating my survey." Are you serious, guys? First off, is any voter really going to see this as a survey? I sincerely hope not. And who do you think you're actually going to convince that it costs $15 to tabulate my survey? I thought the Republicans were supposed to be the party of efficiency... I'm torn on whether I should fill this out 1)as the hardcore leftist 2) seriously (perhaps impossible) or 3) as the most right-wing person I can imagine. What do you guys think?
Well, it's offical; I sent in my deposit today and I'm going to The University of Michigan Law School!
Hmmm, well, I seem to have run out of things to clean and it's too early to start packing. I guess that means I need to pick a law school now, huh?

So, the senior essay is now behind me. Here's what I still have ahead of me between now and graduation: Mac/PC Presentation (4/15) - I'm going over differences between the two operating systems, how to do common tasks, etc. for people who know one but want to learn or are considering switching to the other. It's open to the whole Yale community, though I highly doubt many people are gonna show. Anyone have thoughts on stuff they think I should have? Roman Empire Presentation (4/15) - Fuck this shit; I've gotten almost nothing out of this class and really wish I could have dropped it, but I need it for my last graduate credit. Ugh. I need to read some shit and tell everyone in the class what they say, because Lord knows they're not going to have read it. Pick a Law School (~4/25) - So, I technically have till the end of the month, but I don't want to risk fucking myself over and cutting it too short. I go back and forth by the day between Duke and Michigan and sometimes just want to say 'fuck it' and join the Army, so I really don't know. I think once things calm down after this week, I'm going to put together a long list of my thoughts on it, both to get them out and to send them around and see what people think about my choices. 2 Final Papers (5/9 and ?) - One's gonna be on China's involvement in SE Asian wars during the Cold War (no, it's really not interesting, don't be fooled) and is supposed to be around 20 pages, though it'll prolly be about 15. All I need is a C, so I'll shoot for a B/B+ and I should be fine. As for the other, I have no fucking clue what it's gonna be on, what he's looking for, how long it's supposed to be, when it's due, nothing, so I'm just not worrying about it. That plan can't backfire, can it? In other news, happy 'Black Day' to all my fellow singles out there. http://tinyurl.com/6ce3ys

1) Get a haircut (failed - completed Monday)

2) Do laundry (succeeded!)

3) Go to the gym at least once (failed - completed Monday)

4) Send a bunch of long emails (succeeded!)

and finish my senior essay. That draft I mentioned? Well, it is 'competent and fair,' according to my adviser, but still needs a lot of work. Better than 'incompetent and unfair,' right? (succeeded!)

Edit: And now that it's turned in, I never have to read about the Supreme Court again! Oh, wait...

I think I'm just going to declare today a lost cause and not bother trying to get any work done. 

In other news, I need a girl. Seriously.

I've got a draft. It's 10,500 words long, which is about 2,000 words short of the max, certainly reasonable given the degree to which I tend to add when I edit. I've got a little less than two weeks left to go before the damn thing is due and I'll be running through one round of editing today before submitting it to my adviser to look over while I'm at Duke. Now, it should be mentioned for the sake of clarity that this draft actually sucks (like, really sucks) but I don't think that's something we really need to focus on right now, is it? I should also note that, while this is certainly the biggest thing on my plate right now, I still have two other 25 page papers to write before I can graduate and I haven't even got a topic for either of them. Pfff, no problem...

In case you were wondering, yes, Easter is really freaking early this year. The second earliest possible day, in fact. How can there be an 'earliest possible day' you wonder? Well, as with so much else in Christianity, it's...complicated. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computus From another Wikipedia article on the issue (with my commentary): The calculations for the date of Easter are somewhat complicated. [Ya don't say!] In the Western Church, Easter has not fallen on the earliest of the 35 possible dates, March 22, since 1818, and will not do so again until 2285. [Mark your calendars!] It will, however, fall on March 23 in 2008, but will not do so again until 2160. Easter last fell on the latest possible date, April 25, in 1943 and will next fall on that date in 2038. However, it will fall on April 24, just one day before this latest possible date, in 2011. The cycle of Easter dates repeats after exactly 5,700,000 years, [They sure planned ahead, huh?] with April 19 being the most common date, happening 220,400 times, or 3.9% compared to a mean for all dates of 162,857 times, or 2.9%. In senior essay news, I've got the thing almost halfway written, but I'm more than halfway through my outline, which may prove to be a problem. We'll have to see; if I can get a 10,000 word draft to my adviser before I leave for Duke on the 27th, I'll be golden. Speaking of Duke, there will be a giant "omg, where am I going to go to law school?!?" post at some point, I'm sure. I know you're all oh-so excited.

So, I'm almost done researching this senior essay and, while it's not going to be great, it'll do the job; I've got most of the material I need, and writing the thing should only take a day or two. I'm a little worried that I'm not going to have sufficient material to get to the max length, but I'm thinking my readers won't mind if they have to plow through a couple fewer pages than normal. More importantly, though, I find the fact that this has actually gone quite well (knock on wood) very disturbing; I'm supposed to have been doing on this all year, yet in a few days of work I can catch up and still do the job? What does that say about the history curriculum here, or, more worrisome, about what I've actually learned here? Did I really learn anything or just how to crank out shit that'll do the job? Oh yeah, and I'm struggling to reach normalcy on the other stuff and it's also coming along pretty well despite some setbacks. In order to spare those of you who read this from excessive melo-drama and emo-ness (and because I don't want to get in trouble!) I've taken to writing a quasi-journal on my computer, largely in the form of letters that I'm not going to send. It's been really helpful, but created a weird mental block once I wrote one I am going to send...

Spring cleaning is a good way to keep your mind occupied. I recommend it to all of you out there with more on your plates than you care to deal with. 

Plus, it provides immense amusement for your roommates.

I sometimes wonder how people would respond to what would be undeniably perfectly legal behavior in an airport. Would I get nervous glances and stares (and a call to security?) if I were reading The Anarchist's Bible while waiting for a plane, or if someone glanced over my screen while I was eating at the food court Popeye's and saw pictures of weapons or terrorists? This reminded me of a experiment my friends and I wanted to do in high school; we have a friend who's ethnically Indian but as "red-meat and baseball american" as it gets, has no trace of an accent and is a US citizen but looks scarily like a terrorist if he doesn't shave for a couple days. We wanted to put a towel on his head, like a turban, except position it such that right in the front and center was a Holiday Inn logo or something and see if he could get on a plane. We found the stereotype-bending and absurdity of the idea to be hilarious, but I'm sure that the people on that plane wouldn't. Whether he could get on or not, it would almost certainly have gotten us on a terrorist watch-list or something. Maybe even wondering these things is the reason why I didn't get that FBI internship this summer...

Today, I got a new phone number. It's nice and easy to remember, but it's not the old one, which is more important. Sigh. Here it is:

713-703-7073.

Ugh.

And yes, eventually, I will update about this summer.

So it looks like I'm going to have to bite the bullet and get a Texas phone number. (sigh). I'd been hoping to keep my wonderful 216 forever, but apparently you can't have different area codes on the same family plan and if we all got on a family plan, it would save my parents more than $100 a month. Damnit. They also apparently don't do call-forwarding, so when you switch, you're fucked. How do people do this normally?!?

In other news, this has been one of the busiest and most hectic weeks I've ever had. I have real responsibility and people actually need me to do shit. Gah! That BlackBerry wasn't an idle toy, it seems...I'll write more about that later, but for now I'm going to take a shower, eat some candy and go to bed. Mmmm, bed...

Well, I made it; still not as bad ass as my dad, who drove from Cleveland to Houston straight, only stopping for gas and food, with effectively no one else in the car (Betsey slept and listened to her iPod the whole time and did no driving).

He's got about 35 years on me, but I'm catching up...;-)

So, my dad was asked by The Lancet to do an article on the history of bioethics since the Nuremberg Code in honor of the 60th anniversary of the code; he responded by asking if his "son, a graduate student in history at Yale" (my dad likes to take liberties on occasion...I'm not technically a graduate student since I'm only enrolled in the college, even if I'm getting a masters and taking graduate classes) could co-author it with him. They apparently liked the idea, so he wants us to do it together. It's not really a science paper (which is good, 'cause I suck at those) but it's obviously a major publication, so it'll look good on my resume and it should be fun to do. It's due at the end of July, which gives us two months; he said he had more details and we could go over it when he got home from his trip to Oklahoma City. Yet another thing which would have been impossible before the days of e-mail. I don't know if this will qualify for the paper I have to write for the bioethics internship since I'll be doing it with my dad, but either way, it's pretty sweet. Maybe I can combine them somehow, but if not, I don't mind writing something on top of this article, since it'll be done by July and the bioethics thing doesn't have to be in until August. There's also no guarantee that this will get published, but on the other extreme, if I write this and another one for the program, I could get two published papers out of this summer. Wouldn't that be cool. Too much to think about right now with these damn LSATs breathing down my throat. I think I messed up that metaphor... Meg's coming home tomorrow morning. Tim gets home at like 10 at night. :-D It'll be great to have them home, but I'm not gonna lie, I'm excited to get back to New Haven. I miss someone. ;-)

There are two main purposes to this entry. One is to waste time since I don't want to do any more work on the LSATs and the other is to finish my review of Friedman's The World is Flat. So, let's begin. Yeah, I said it; he needed to read his own damn book. What are the two purposes this would have served? Well, for one, it would have told him that it needed to be at least a hundred and fifty pages shorter. At over 450 pages, the thing was way too long; I got to around page 325 and just really wanted it to end, though that was admittedly in part due to the particular subject matter of that section (I'm getting to that). Basically, a significant part of the book is him giving anecdotes about all the things he's seen and heard that make him convinced of his theories. These were (for the most part) interesting, but there were way, way, too many of them. There were sections where he'd have like, 3 pages of examples and then basically say "See?" Sorry, Tom, but that's not why I'm reading this book. The other thing a reading would have done was show him that he's missing out on the basic lessons of his book, basically that 1) we're getting lazy and we don't have that luxury anymore and 2) things are different now and we'd better get used to it 'cause it's gonna happen whether we like it or not. Where does he forget those lessons? Well, in a section (the one which includes page 325) where he coins this innane term "compassionate flatism" (I guess we have W. to thank for the inspiration) which basically means taking the failed ideas of the New Deal and the Great Society and thinking they'll work this time around. He calls people who just want to let the system work and not try to protect people from it "cruel" and "fools". Maybe it's because he's talking about yours truly and some of my good friends, I couldn't help but be frustrated by this, since just about every word of the book to that point pointed to the fact that this kind of compassion is misguided and counter-productive at best and downright stupid at worst. He makes a huge deal out of the fact that in India and China, where the choices are work and succeed or pull a rickshaw, people succeed more and better than do lazy Americans and Europeans who have a sense of entitlement. How exactly does he think we're going to stress this need to work and persevere if we protect people from the 'evils' of the market? Freidman knows better, but the liberal Minnesotan in him just won't accept that the days of socialist protections and the welfare state are over, and not a moment too soon. This is notably annoying in one passage where he describes a conversation with a friend of his from back home about how technological advances had forced him to do more work for less money and about the increased competition that the same advances had created. The guy was whining about how this was so unfair and he hated it. Friedman, a guy who had just spent several desperately-in-need-of-editing pages ranting about how this kind of thing benefits everyone overall because it reduces prices and increases quality over all industries, listened and didn't tell the guy what many readers of the book must have been shouting in their heads: Buck up and grow a pair, man! I know Friedman probably can't say that to his friend and is even less likely to write it in a book, but it should have been the message, but it wasn't. The take away point from this section seemed to be "this is gonna be hard for people so we need to be careful and listen to their feelings and be ready to mellow things out". Are you kidding me? I understand the idea that we risk a backlash from people who are angry and unemployed and don't get the way the system functions on the aggregate (who don't understand that while they lost their job at the steel mill because of imports, those imports are the reason that everything from everything from cars to fridges is cheaper, which benefits them, their relatives, their kids and everyone else in the country). That's why I probably would have voted for the New Deal in the 30s; if we didn't make a capitalism people would accept, there was a real chance we'd get something far worse. But guess what? We're not there right now. We have a thriving economy and a legitimate, working banking system and there isn't a threat of revolt just 'cause there are some pissed off teamsters. The time has long since passed when the threat justified the brakes these types of concessions put on the economy, and the need to remove those breaks is getting greater and greater by the minute. Friedman knows this, he wrote the damn book, afterall, but he just isn't willing to see it. That's why I'd actually have liked to see Stossel on Friedman; besides the wonderful irony that Stossel, a TV guy, wrote a much better book than Friedman, a newspaper columnist, he's much more willing to cut through the ideological assumptions and see what's really going on. He's not perfect, but at least he's more honest about what he's arguing and what he's assuming and, at least to me, these assumptions and arguments make a lot more sense than the New York Times, liberal, guilt-driven welfare state. All that being said (this may come as a shock) I really did like the book overall. It should have been shorter and he should have been willing to go the next step, but it was a very interesting read, particularly at the beginning and the end. While it got tedious in the middle, the end made up a lot of the difference when he went back to what he does best: geopolitics. His discussion of the role of al-Qaeda and his new "Dell Theory of Conflict Resolution" were really interesting and very enjoyable. Ironically, I think that stuff could have been its own book, or at least taken the place of the excessive use of examples from the first part. Overall, I'd recommend the book, though Lexus and the Olive Tree is better. I'm definitely going to read his immediately post-9/11 book on terrorism, a book I didn't even know about until starting this one, and I'll give you guys a fun update on that that you can read or ignore at your leisure. Phew. Well, that's all I have to say about Friedman. The LSATs are driving me insane, as my Facebook status can attest to, and I just really want them to be done. I don't think I've really made any improvement, to be honest, which is the most frustrating part of this whole thing. June 12th can't come soon enough...

Ladies and Gentlemen, I have found an amazing podcast. It's called "Ask a Ninja" and when I say "I found" I mean "Jay showed me."

Regardless, it's awesome. You can find it here at www.askaninja.com. My personal favorites are:

What is Podcasting?

(Note: This one contains a hilarious and wacky and yet brilliant and very accurate description of the podcasting phenomenon and its popularity.)

Review of Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest

These last two are hilarious in particular because of their rapid-fire answer format. Most of the videos are based on one theme or question he's gotten, but these two are just going through them like JLo and husbands.

Omnibus

Omnideuce

Anyways, these are my personal favorites, but I encourage you to waste a couple hours and go through them to find your own (the recent ones are better than the old ones in my opinion). You can also subscribe to it for free on iTunes, though the quality isn't as good as on the site in my opinion. Plus they're pretty good sized files and take up a lot of space if you keep them all. (shrug). Anyways, there goes one of my promised updates. Enjoy.

I came across this article during my random internet surfing and just loved it. I sent it out to two of my panlists under the subject line of "this is america" because [begin sarcasm] it says so much about the downright amazing people who live in this country.[end dripping sarcasm] God can I be condescending sometimes...anyways, here's the article. http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/LegalCenter/story?id=3195632&page=1 My favorite parts: They're identical twins who slept with the same woman on the same day...at a rodeo! and are now duking it out in a paternity suit. How can it better than that? Well, in case you need more... "Raymon's [no, not 'Raymond'] the one that done everything." The fact that they don't show the woman (she must be even fatter and uglier than the guys) but splice the picture of the brothers so they're looking at each other a la Colbert and himself. The fact that she shows up at this guy's room drunk and looking for sex (she must have been really desperate) and then returns to the other's and sleeps with him. Wow. An update on more relevant (I almost typed 'interesting' and then caught myself) stuff is in the works. Man oh man...

So, yesterday morning I had an interesting e-mail in my inbox. It was from Dell, a guy named 'Brad' to be specific, and it said that he had "come across my blog post and saw that you described a problem with your Dell system. Please contact me back if you are still having issues with the system and I will help you in any way that I can."

For those of you who don't remember the update in question, it was this one which had a one phrase mention of having to redo a motherboard replacement I had to redo as a result of a bad part Dell had sent as a replacement. Well, I was initially kinda weirded out by this; I mean, this thing is public, obviously, and I've learned not to put anything on here that I'm not ready to have anyone see, but it was like "why is Dell reading my LJ?" I asked someone at Dell about this and it turns out that they have a "new team that reaches out to customers through their blogs or forum posts" and they had come across my entry.

I can understand why this is a really good idea; Yale has a great support system for its students and even within the support structure, there are really good options for people who need help (read: e-mailing Minh and frantically asking for help), but if I didn't have that (and I didn't used to), I can appreciate how frustrating it would be to not be able to fix your computer. I gotta hand it to Dell for this one...good idea, guys. Just try not to bee TOO creepy with it. ;-)

After all, it's not the weirdest random response to an entry I've ever gotten. That title goes to this one (note in particular her past userpics).

Now, I should probably get some stuff done since I've been all around quite unproductive today. Cheers

I've written 2,700 of 4,000 words and I'm completely out of things to say.

FUCK

so, I went to take a shower, but I when I got into the bathroom, I opened the door to find the floor of the shower covered with what looked like pizza crumbs. I turned on the water to try and wash them down, but to no avail. I could have tried to clean it up, but I just said fuck it 'cause I was in no mood. So Jonny's going to sleep mildly sweaty and stinky tonight! These fucking seniors across the hall, man...I'm so ready to be rid of them. In other news, my room is mostly packed up and my plan seems to be working [knock on wood]. We'll see how it goes. Tomorrow is pretty free except for class (class?!? why the hell do I have class tomorrow?!?), tutoring and a re-do of a motherboard replacement since Dell sent us a bad one the first time around. Pack up the stuff going to the Andrews and then Friday I've got the concert and the final packing. I'm just leaving most of the shit in my car in the garage (possibly not the best of ideas) and getting it when I come back. We'll see how that goes...

When I start up my computer, I get a log-in box for 'coloradosheep.com'. I swear, I haven't looked at sheep porn in months. Ok, weeks, but still.

My computer has been running progressively slower for a while now, so it could use, as James said, a 'colonoscopy'. Once I can get home and back-up all my data, maybe get Office 2007, too, then I'll go ahead and wipe the thing clean. I would get a new HD, too, but I see no reason to spend more money on this computer when I'm gonna be hopefully getting a new one in a year anyways. (shrug). Maybe I should just get a new one...

In other news, I got done with my other paper. Yay! Just one to go, as well as my China final tomorrow. I can do this, I can do this...the other side of the junior year is within my grasp!

I cleaned up the mess to a limited degree, but I'll still have to wash the pillow cases. We're leaving this room in a week, so the rest doesn't really matter. I must admit, it was quite hilarious, even if I felt like a colossal moron.  Well, at least now we know it works. :-)

I'm ahead of schedule: paper 1 has been submitted, paper 2 is in the process of being edited and expanded, paper 3 has been researched (and may even be done by the normal due date, despite the extension I got), studying for my final is under control, and paper 4 is a distant, distant threat. 

I've got this under control [knock on wood].

I just wrote the following sentence: 

"The focus of health care is more and more on the elderly, with the main goal of separating 'getting old' from 'getting dick'."

Typos, man; they get me every time. Now, back to this paper...
I just got a 100 sugar cookies and a big bucket of frosting. Oh, the possibilities... And what does it say about me that this is my first update in almost three weeks?
The Cantab hath returned, the family is complete...if only for 36 hours. Let the bickering and arguing begin!

I have once again demonstrated the dastardly conspiracy of the evil forces which call themselves 'modern dentistry.' I went to the dentist today and was told that I have "beautiful teeth" and that they're in "great condition." This for a guy who hasn't flossed in years*, who only brushes once a day and who eats more candy than any other human being he's ever come into contact with. Come on, people...if you're gonna orchestrate a worldwide conspiracy, at least be more careful about how you hand out praise and criticism. The other funny thing that happened at the dentist was that when I got there and told them I was a new patient (I'd yet to go in Houston) they pulled up the Markman file which had "Tomes Markman" as the first entry. "Oh," the dental hygienist asked me, "does your wife come here?" No, ma'am, I'm twenty; that's my mom. Thanks, though... In other news, my efforts at getting in better shape and getting a tan seem to be failing quite miserably. I think I lost tan today even though I was in the sun with only minimal sunscreen application for over an hour and a half. Tomorrow's gonna be cloudy and it's supposed to rain starting Thursday, but hopefully I'll get another dash of sun in before returning to NE, the land which God hath forsaken. Ugh, back to work. *the last time I flossed was when I conducted an experiment; because it seemed like the only negative thing my dentist ever said about my teeth was that I should floss more, I went a 6-month period when I flossed basically every day (a real difficult task, given that I didn't even brush every day...ok, not even every other) to see what he'd say. Of course, as I'd predicted, he made another lame joke about flossing more and I became determined that flossing was a giant hoax.

My mom gave me a magazine of cool ranch real estate stuff and I was looking through it this afternoon as I ate candy and procrastinated. Should have been doing LSAT studying, but I'm lazy and a procrastinator, you know that. Anyways, there's a company in there selling pieces of a giant block of land (37,500 acres) up near the Oklahoma border for $690 an acre. Here's the site for the ranch: http://www.nofencesland.com/ranch.php?id=72

I was stunned. Land here in West U, an area of Houston near Rice where I live, goes for like a million an acre and this stuff was less than $700! Granted, it's probably not great land and it's not in a prime location, but for 700 bucks it doesn't have to be. I'm not gonna lie, I was really tempted to give them a call and see what's the minimum block you can get; I could buy ten acres and just hold onto it for a couple decades and see what happens...turns out that the whole "$690 and acre" thing was just a way of covering up the fact that you have to pay over 25 million or it; they don't just sell pieces. Damnit, you guys got my hopes up and everything...

In other news, I'm driving up to Dallas tomorrow at like 5 in the morning to take Bets up and check out SMU. Hopefully I'll get to say hola to the Schweikerts while we're up there, but it should be a nice day and I feel like I haven't driven on the highway in so long. Oh, wait, my bad...it's been three days.

"Everyone deals with their mortality in different ways. I have responded by studying history. To me, the great men of history - Caesar, Washington, Nelson - never died; they live on through their writings, and the writings of others about them, guiding and teaching me as they have countless others. I naively believe that I will be the same and, as such, I will never die."

I don't list the source of the quote or who it came from, and this is an old notebook judging by the handwriting in it, but clearly it spoke to me then and it still does today. I guess the guy who wrote it was wrong, though, since I clearly didn't know who he was or it didn't matter enough to record it; I can't decide if I find that depressing or not...

I'll write an update about this college trip I just got home from at some point, but now all I want is some of my mom's chicken soup.
I'm off. Tejas, here we come...

"There are two kinda of problem drinkers: those that drink too much and those that drink too little."
- Winston Churchill on Neville Chamberlain

This is the beginning to a 750 page book I have to read for Monday morning: "In writing of what Yankees call 'the Civil War,' what red-blooded Southrons call 'the War of Northern Aggression,' and what we prefer to call 'the War for Southern Independence,' we here simply refer to 'the War.' For Southerners - liberal and conservative, black and white - and for no few Northerners as well, there was, after all, only one war that really mattered." Wow. First off, people still call each other Yankees? I mean, the book was written in 2005, for crying out loud. Second, is 'Southrons' even a word? [Edit: apparently it's a generic word for 'Southerner' from the Civil War but now is used to refer to 'Southern Patriots', people who are apparently still fighting the Civil War (excuse me, the War for Southern Independence). Most references I found, though, are to to the people by that name in The Lord of the Rings] Third...are you serious? 'only one war that really mattered'? WWII? Vietnam? I think these two had some effect on society. Maybe. I suspect these types of shock will run throughout my 'reading' (by which I, of course, mean 'skimming') of it.

There are few things more peaceful than snowfall. Too bad I can't stay up to watch it tonight...or can I?

Two years ago, the falling of snow always seemed to foretell doom for me. Hopefully this year it'll mean the opposite. 

I have faith.

I went to the ATM this weekend while I was in NYC and it felt very strange; I couldn't put my finger on why. When I sat down at my computer to note it in my records (yes, I keep records of all my expenditures on my computer...don't tell me you're surprised) I saw that the last time I went to the ATM was November 10th How the hell did I go 2 and a half months without getting cash?!?
